Question: What is the relationship between Noonan syndrome and polycystic renal disease?
Free_form_answer: Noonan's syndrome is an eponymic designation that has been used during the last 8 years to describe a variable constellation of somatic and visceral congenital anomalies, which includes groups of patients previously referred to as male Turner's, female pseudo-Turner's and Bonnevie-Ullrich syndromes. It is now recognized that both sexes may show the stigmas of this condition and, unlike Turner's syndrome, there is no karyotype abnormality although there is often a familial pattern. The most commonly observed anomalies include webbing of the neck, hypertelorism, a shield-shaped chest and short stature. Congenital heart disease, principally pulmonary stenosis, and sexual infantilism often with cryptorchidism in the male subject are additional associated anomalies in this syndrome. Renal anomalies have been described rarely and usually consist of rotational errors, duplications and hydronephrosis. We report the first case of an infant who displayed many of the stigmas of Noonan's syndrome and also showed early evidence of frank renal failure secondary to renal dysplasia with cystic disease.
Must_have: Noonan's syndrome is a congenital condition involving somatic and visceral anomalies.
It is generally seen in both sexes and typically shows familial patterns.
Renal anomalies have been rarely associated with Noonan's syndrome usually consisting of rotational errors, duplications, and hydronephrosis.
A case has been documented of an infant with several characteristics of Noonan's syndrome who also presented with renal failure due to renal dysplasia with cystic disease.
Nice_to_have: The common anomalies observed in Noonan's syndrome include neck webbing, extreme spacing between the eyes, a shield-shaped chest, and short stature.
Congenital heart illness, particularly pulmonary stenosis, and sexual underdevelopment, often accompanied by undescended testicles in males, are other entities correlated with this syndrome.
The karyotype of patients with Noonan's syndrome does not typically show any abnormalities.

The film coated tablets contain anhydrous lactose NF, microcrystalline cellulose NF, sodium starch glycolate NF, magnesium stearate NF, hydroxypropyl methylcellulose USP, titanium dioxide USP, polyethylene glycol 400 NF, yellow iron oxide NF (2.5 mg tablet), red iron oxide NF (5 mg tablet), and polyethylene glycol 8000 NF. Zolmitriptan orally disintegrating tablets are available as 2.5 mg and 5 mg white uncoated tablets. The orally disintegrating tablets contain mannitol USP, microcrystalline cellulose NF, crospovidone NF, aspartame NF [see WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS (5.9)], sodium bicarbonate USP, citric acid anhydrous USP, colloidal silicon dioxide NF, magnesium stearate NF and orange flavor SN 027512.

Question: What are the treatments and precautions for VDRL positive (syphilis) patients?
Free_form_answer: Syphilis If the RPR, VDRL, or TRUST tests are positive, one of the following tests will be needed to confirm the diagnosis: FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody test); MHA-TP; TP-EIA; TP-PA. Syphilis can be treated with antibiotics, such as: Doxycycline (type of tetracycline given to people who are allergic to penicillin); Penicillin G benzathine. Length of treatment depends on how severe the syphilis is, and factors such as the person's overall health. Several hours after getting treatment for the early stages of syphilis, people may experience the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction. This process is caused by an immune reaction to the breakdown products of the infection. Follow-up blood tests must be done at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months to ensure that the infection is gone. Avoid sexual contact when the chancre is present. Use condoms until two follow-up tests have shown that the infection has been cured, to reduce the chance of transmitting the infection. All sexual partners of the person with syphilis should also be treated. Syphilis can spread very easily in the primary and secondary stages.
Must_have: Syphilis can be diagnosed through tests such as RPR, VDRL, TRUST, FTA-ABS, MHA-TP, TP-EIA, and TP-PA.
The treatment of Syphilis includes antibiotics like Doxycycline or Penicillin G benzathine.
Anyone who has been diagnosed with syphilis must undergo follow-up blood tests at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months to ensure the infection is eliminated.
Sexual precautionary measures, such as avoiding sexual contact with the chancre and using condoms until the infection gets cured, should be taken to reduce the risk of transmission.
All sexual partners of the Syphilis patient needs to be treated as well.
Nice_to_have: People may experience the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction after getting treatment for the early stages of syphilis, due to an immune response to the breakdown products of the infection.
Syphilis can spread very easily in the primary and secondary stages.
The duration of treatment can vary depending on the severity of the infection and individual's overall health.
Therefore, it is crucial to follow the recommended treatment regimen and precautions to prevent further spread and reinfection.

Question: Can a birth control drug called Ocella cause Deep Vein Thrombosis?
Free_form_answer: Some studies show that women who take oral contraceptives that contain drosperinone (Beyaz, Gianvi, Loryna, Ocella, Safyral, Syeda, Yasmin, Yaz, and Zarah) may be more likely to develop deep vein thrombosis (a serious or life-threatening condition in which blood clots that form in the veins, usually in the legs and may move through the body to the lungs) than women who take oral contraceptives that do not contain drosperinone. However, other studies do not show this increased risk. Before you begin taking oral contraceptives, talk to your doctor about the risk that you will develop blood clots and about which oral contraceptive or other method of birth control may be the best choice for you.Oral contraceptives may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.
Must_have: Oral contraceptives that contain drosperinone, including Ocella, have been associated with a potential increased risk of deep vein thrombosis.
It is essential to discuss the potential risk of blood clot formation with a healthcare provider before starting any oral contraceptive.
Nice_to_have: There have been varying results from studies looking at the risk of deep vein thrombosis with the use of oral contraceptives containing drosperinone, with some studies finding an increased risk and others not.
Additionally, other side effects are associated with oral contraceptives and any unusual problems experienced while taking this medication should be reported to a doctor.

Question: Can a streptococcus infection cause other diseases such as wegeners?
Free_form_answer: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), previously known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is a rare disease. The cause of GPA is unknown. It can affect people at any age. Men and women are equally affected. It is more common in whites. Symptoms may include joint pain, weakness, tiredness, and cold symptoms such as a runny nose that doesn't get better. Doctors use blood tests, chest X-rays, and biopsies to diagnose GPA and rule out other causes of the symptoms.
Must_have: The cause of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), also previously known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is currently unknown.
Diagnosing GPA involves blood tests, chest X-rays, and biopsies to rule out other causes of symptoms.
Nice_to_have: Symptoms of GPA can include joint pain, weakness, tiredness, and cold-like symptoms such as a runny nose that doesn't improve.
GPA is a rare disease that can affect anyone at any age and affects men and women equally.
It is more common in whites.
Hence, there are no known connections between streptococcal infections and GPA.

Question: Could or does second hand smoke contribute or is a cause for getting Early AMD?
Free_form_answer: Smoking increases a person's chances of developing AMD by two to five fold. Because the retina has a high rate of oxygen consumption, anything that affects oxygen delivery to the retina may affect vision. Smoking causes oxidative damage, which may contribute to the development and progression of this disease. Learn more about why smoking damages the retina, and explore a number of steps you can take to protect your vision.
Must_have: Smoking increases the risk of developing AMD (Age-related Macular Degeneration) by two to fivefold.
Smoking causes oxidative damage, which may influence the development and progression of AMD.
Nice_to_have: Since the retina has a high rate of oxygen consumption, any factors that impede oxygen delivery may have an impact on vision.
There are various measures a person can take to safeguard their vision, such as quitting smoking.
Secondhand smoke, while not as harmful as active smoking, still contains chemicals and toxins that can potentially contribute to ocular diseases such as early AMD.
However, direct evidence linking secondhand smoke exposure with early AMD development remains scarce and this is an area of ongoing research.

Free_form_answer: Hydatidiform mole (HM) is a rare mass or growth that forms inside the womb (uterus) at the beginning of a pregnancy. It is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD). HM, or molar pregnancy, results from abnormal fertilization of the oocyte (egg). It results in an abnormal fetus. The placenta grows normally with little or no growth of the fetal tissue. The placental tissue forms a mass in the uterus. On ultrasound this mass often has a grape-like appearance, as it contains many small cysts.
Must_have: A molar pregnancy, or Hydatidiform mole, results from an abnormal fertilization process.
It often leads to the growth of an abnormal fetus and an unusual growth of placental tissue that forms a mass in the uterus.
Nice_to_have: Hydatidiform mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease that forms at the beginning of a pregnancy and is characterized by the appearance of a grape-like mass on an ultrasound, due to many small cysts.

Question: How do symptoms of arthritis differ from onset of HNPP, and what are the treatments for these respective disorders?
Free_form_answer: Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies is characterized by recurrent episodes of numbness, tingling, and loss of muscle function (palsy) in the region associated with the affected nerve, usually an arm, hand, leg, or foot. An episode can last from several minutes to several months, but recovery is usually complete. Repeated incidents, however, can cause permanent muscle weakness or loss of sensation. This disorder is also associated with pain in the limbs, especially the hands. Arthritis symptoms include pain, stiffness, swelling, and decreased range of motion in the joints. The symptoms can be mild, moderate, or severe, and can affect one or multiple joints. They may come and go, or stay consistently. Over time, arthritis can cause joints to deform and can affect normal functioning.Treatment for HNPP typically involves management of the symptoms. Avoiding injury or pressure on the affected nerves, using protective pads at pressure areas in casts or splints, and physical therapy can help. Medications can be used to manage the pain. Overall, the management of HNPP involves avoiding triggering factors and maintaining a healthy lifestyle to prevent nerve damage.Treatment for Arthritis varies, depending on the type of arthritis. Some common treatments include anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy, lifestyle modifications like diet and exercise, and in severe cases, surgery.

Treatment for arthritis can include anti-inflammatory medications, physical therapy, lifestyle modifications, and surgery.

HNPP is characterized by recurrent episodes of numbness, tingling and loss of muscle function, usually in an arm, hand, leg, or foot and the treatment typically involves managing the symptoms, protective measures, physical therapy, and medications to manage pain.
Nice_to_have: Arthritis symptoms can be mild, moderate, or severe, affecting one or multiple joints, and may come and go or be persistent.
HNPP can cause permanent muscle weakness or loss of sensation if there are repeated incidents.
Treatment for HNPP involves avoiding triggers and maintaining a healthy lifestyle to prevent nerve damage.
In severe cases of arthritis, surgery may be required.

Question: How do I find out if my fibromyalgia is genetic?
Free_form_answer: Is fibromyalgia hereditary? Answers from Kevin C. Fleming, M.D. Fibromyalgia isn't passed directly from parents to children, but the disorder does appear to cluster within families. The odds of developing fibromyalgia are several times higher in the immediate families of people with fibromyalgia than in families in which no one has fibromyalgia. In fact, studies of DNA from family members of people with fibromyalgia and other chronic pain syndromes have turned up a number of genes that could help explain why these disorders seem to run in families. Each of these genes plays a role in your nervous system's response to pain. Some of the same genes are also associated with depression and anxiety, which may be the reason why certain antidepressant medications help reduce fibromyalgia symptoms.
Must_have: Fibromyalgia is not directly passed from parents to children.
The disorder does tend to cluster within families.
The chances of developing fibromyalgia are higher in families with a history of the disorder.
There are certain genes that are associated with the increased risk of fibromyalgia, which play a role in your nervous system's response to pain.
Nice_to_have: Studies of DNA from family members of people with fibromyalgia have identified a number of genes that could help explain why the disorder seems to run in families.
Some of the same genes associated with fibromyalgia are also linked with depression and anxiety, which may explain why certain antidepressant medications can help reduce fibromyalgia symptoms.

Washington DC (JNS) Hair strands and wigs from Russia to Scotland, from America to Africa -- all on one strand.

Washington's chopping-block hairs, George IV's miniature wig, long plaits from Czeck laundresses and Chinese maids, a 135-centimeter-long dreadlock from America, and maybe even a lock from Queen Victoria will make up the Hair Museum in the National Museum of American History of the Smithsonian in Washington DC.

"This is inspired by a look back into hair's history," said Karen Fishwick, newly hired hair museum curator, last week. "And it is also looking into hair's future."

Barbers and hairdressers from the Philadelphia region and representatives from the George Washington University Medical Center also attended the opening ceremony.

A highlight of the display is the hair of Maria Theresa of Austria, one of the only 17 th century queens who could look back on nearly 100 husbands, said Fishwick. Maria Theresa is thought to be the grandmother of Napoleon Bonaparte.

Her husband, Joseph II, relaxed the Habsburg dynasty's rules and thus brought about the observed existence of the modern Europe. She moved from Munich to Vienna to settle the question of a new throne. That is, so far, historian's conjecture. Maria Theresa's first husband, Franz Stephan, died surprisingly early with Allan houses, together with Allen whips, served as entertainment for ladies. As a result, wigs enjoyed status as aristocratic accessories.

"The hair museum is not a typical museum," said Fishwick. "It's an experimental laboratory for hair."

American braiders and artisans as well as European experts have contributed to the new hair museum, along with their own hairstyles and strands. But all of the hair and wig strands are natural, said Fishwick, and non-polluting.

Question: The questioner is seeking information on a condition that affects children and is called Oppositional Defiant Disorder.
Free_form_answer: Oppositional defiant disorder is a pattern of disobedient, hostile, and defiant behavior toward authority figures. This disorder is more common in boys than in girls. Some studies have shown that it affects 20% of school-age children. However, most experts believe this figure is high due to changing definitions of normal childhood behavior. It may also possibly have racial, cultural, and gender biases.
Must_have: Oppositional defiant disorder is known for manifesting as a pattern of disobedient, hostile, and defiant behavior toward authority figures in children.
The behavior must be lasting for at least 6 months, and be more than normal misbehavior for a child's age and developmental level.
The behaviors should lead to significant problems in school or social activities.
A mental health professional should evaluate children presenting symptoms of oppositional defiant disorder.
Nice_to_have: It typically starts by age 8, but may begin as early as the preschool years, and it affects more boys than girls.
Treatment often involves individual and possibly family therapy, with parents learning to manage the child's behavior.
Medication may also be beneficial, especially if other conditions such as depression, childhood psychosis, or ADHD are present.
Some children respond well to treatment, while others do not.
The disorder is possibly influenced by biological, psychological, and social factors.
Instances of this disorder may potentially be influenced by biases related to race, culture, and gender.

Question: I want information on Beckwith-Wieddeman Syndrome.
Free_form_answer: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body. It is classified as an overgrowth syndrome, which means that affected infants are considerably larger than normal (macrosomia) and tend to be taller than their peers during childhood. Growth begins to slow by about age 8, and adults with this condition are not unusually tall. In some children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, specific parts of the body on one side or the other may grow abnormally large, leading to an asymmetric or uneven appearance. This unusual growth pattern, which is known as hemihyperplasia, usually becomes less apparent over time. The signs and symptoms of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome vary among affected individuals. Some children with this condition are born with an opening in the wall of the abdomen (an omphalocele) that allows the abdominal organs to protrude through the belly-button. Other abdominal wall defects, such as a soft out-pouching around the belly-button (an umbilical hernia), are also common. Some infants with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have an abnormally large tongue (macroglossia), which may interfere with breathing, swallowing, and speaking. Other major features of this condition include abnormally large abdominal organs (visceromegaly), creases or pits in the skin near the ears, low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) in infancy, and kidney abnormalities. Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at an increased risk of developing several types of cancerous and noncancerous tumors, particularly a form of kidney cancer called Wilms tumorand a form of liver cancer called hepatoblastoma. Tumors develop in about 10 percent of people with this condition and almost always appear in childhood. Most children and adults with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome do not have serious medical problems associated with the condition. Their life expectancy is usually normal.
Must_have: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth condition, which could lead to greater than average size in infancy and childhood.
It could result in asymmetric or uneven body appearance due to abnormal growth of specific body parts.

It could also involve major features like an opening in the abdomen (omphalocele), large tongue (macroglossia), larger than normal abdominal organs (visceromegaly), skin creases or pits near the ears, low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), kidney abnormalities.
Children with this syndrome are susceptible to cancerous and noncancerous tumors such as Wilms' tumor and hepatoblastoma.
These tumors usually appear in childhood.
Nice_to_have: The growth in those with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome tends to slow down by about age 8 and as adults, they are not particularly tall.
The unusual growth pattern known as hemihyperplasia, usually becomes less apparent over time.
Other abdominal wall defects common to this condition include a soft out-pouching around the belly-button (an umbilical hernia).
The large tongue could interfere with breathing, swallowing, and speech.
Most people with this syndrome do not have major medical issues and life expectancy is typically normal.

The choice of drug for treatment can depend on the patient’s medical history, the type of Citrobacter species causing the infection, and the site of the infection.

Question: Is bloody drainage normal with otitis media after starting antibiotics?
Free_form_answer: With a severe ear infection, pressure may build up and cause the eardrum to rupture. Pus and blood may drain out. This usually relieves pain and pressure, and in most cases the eardrum heals on its own.
Must_have: Bloody drainage from the ear is not normally expected with otitis media during antibiotic treatment.
If you observe bloody drainage from the ear, it's crucial to communicate this to your healthcare provider immediately.
Nice_to_have: If ear pressure from otitis media gets severe, it may cause the eardrum to rupture, leading to pus and blood draining out, which often gives a sense of relief from pain.
However, not all bloody drainage from the ear means ruptured eardrum, and it is critical to consult with a healthcare professional.

Question: Is dementia inherited? Can one develop dementia without inheriting it?
Free_form_answer:
Scientists know genes are involved in Alzheimer's. Two categories of genes influence whether a person develops a disease: risk genes and deterministic genes. Alzheimer's genes have been found in both categories.
 1. Risk genes increase the likelihood of developing a disease, but do not guarantee it will happen. Researchers have found several genes that increase the risk of Alzheimer's. apolipoprotein E-e4, or APOE-e4, is the first risk gene identified and remains the one with strongest impact. 2. Deterministic genes directly cause a disease, guaranteeing that anyone who inherits one will develop the disorder. Scientists have discovered variations that directly cause Alzheimer's disease in the genes coding three proteins: amyloid precursor protein (APP), presenilin-1 (PS-1) and presenilin-2 (PS-2).
Must_have: Alzheimer's disease, one form of dementia, is influenced by both risk genes and deterministic genes.
Risk genes, such as apolipoprotein E-e4, increase the likelihood of developing the disease but do not guarantee it.
Deterministic genes, including those coding for the proteins APP, PS-1, and PS-2, directly cause the disease and guarantee its development in those who inherit them.
Inheritance of these genes only accounts for a fraction of Alzheimer's cases, however, and most dementia cases are not direct outcomes of genetics.
Nice_to_have: Factors like lifestyle, age, and overall health can also contribute to the development of dementia.
It's also worth noting that while genes can influence whether a person might develop Alzheimer's, they're not the sole factor.
Non-genetic factors, such as cardiovascular disease, stroke, diabetes, and hypertension, have also been associated with an increased risk of dementia.

Question: How much urine does an average human bladder hold, in fluid oz., cups or milliliters (ml)?
Free_form_answer: Normal functional bladder capacity in adults ranges from approximately 300 to 400 ml (58,59).
Must_have: The urge to urinate typically begins when the bladder is about a fourth of its capacity.
The average adult human bladder can hold between 300 to 400 milliliters of urine.
Holding urine for too long can lead to urinary tract infections or bladder damage.

Nice_to_have: In terms of other units of measurements, the bladder's capacity is about 10 to 13.5 fluid ounces or about 1.27 to 1.69 cups.
This bladder capacity is equivalent to approximately 10 to 14 fluid ounces or approximately 1 to 1.7 cups.
There is little difference in bladder capacity between men and women, with men's bladders typically able to hold slightly more.

Question: How do I safely dispose of Hydrogen Peroxide?

Containers that held hydrogen peroxide should be thoroughly rinsed before disposal or recycling.
Nice_to_have: If you have a larger quantity of hydrogen peroxide to dispose of, it is better to seek advice from your local waste disposal facility or a hazardous waste disposal company.

Question: What are the causes of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? Are there long-term pulmonary sequelae? Can marrying your cousin cause this?
Free_form_answer: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) can occur as an isolated finding, as part of a genetic syndrome or chromosome abnormality, or with additional birth defects of unknown cause.[5] Some cases have been linked to in utero exposures.[6] In the majority of cases, the cause is not known.[5]Specific genetic or environmental factors that increase the risk for CDH include certain gene mutations, use of certain medications during pregnancy, smoking during pregnancy, and having a parent with a history of CDH.As for the question regarding marrying a cousin, while studies have found an increased risk of birth defects including congenital diaphragmatic hernia in children born to parents who are cousins, it's important to note that the overall risk remains relatively low. Such consanguinity is one of the numerous factors that could potentially contribute to the condition, and the individual risk is influenced by many factors including the specifics of the family's genetic makeup.Long-term pulmonary sequelae are possible, as untreated CDH can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia or underdevelopment of the lungs, which may cause respiratory distress, pulmonary hypertension, and potentially longer-term lung function abnormalities. However, with proper medical intervention and management, many individuals with CDH can have a good quality of life.
Must_have: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can occur as an isolated matter, part of a genetic syndrome, or chromosome abnormality, or along with additional unknown birth defects.
Cases of CDH have been linked to certain gene mutations, use of certain medications during pregnancy, smoking during pregnancy, and having a parent with CDH.
Nice_to_have: Marrying a cousin can slightly increase the risk of CDH in offspring, but the overall risk and impact are influenced by many factors.

Long-term pulmonary sequelae, such as pulmonary hypoplasia or underdevelopment of the lungs, may occur in untreated cases of CDH, leading to potential respiratory distress and longer-term lung function abnormalities.
With appropriate medical intervention, many individuals with CDH can experience a good quality of life.

Question: Is the shingles virus contagious in the workplace, especially where food is being prepared?
Free_form_answer: Shingles cannot be passed from one person to another. However, the virus that causes shingles, the varicella zoster virus, can be spread from a person with active shingles to another person who has never had chickenpox. In such cases, the person exposed to the virus might develop chickenpox, but they would not develop shingles. The virus is spread through direct contact with fluid from the rash blisters caused by shingles. A person with active shingles can spread the virus when the rash is in the blister-phase. A person is not infectious before the blisters appear. Once the rash has developed crusts, the person is no longer contagious. Shingles is less contagious than chickenpox and the risk of a person with shingles spreading the virus is low if the rash is covered.
Must_have: The varicella zoster virus, which causes shingles, can be spread from a person with active shingles to another person who has not had chickenpox.
The virus is spread through direct contact with fluid from the rash blisters caused by shingles.
A person with active shingles is not infectious before the blisters appear.
After the rash has developed crusts, the person is no longer contagious.
Nice_to_have: Shingles on its own cannot be passed from person to person.
The virus that causes shingles can lead to chickenpox in a person who has never had it, but not shingles.
Shingles is less contagious than chickenpox and the risk of spreading the virus is low if the rash is covered.

Consequently, a person with shingles working in a food preparation environment should be cautious, as contact with food may potentially spread the virus to others who have not had chickenpox, leading to their developing chickenpox rather than shingles.

Traci Ferrell, Registered Environmental Health Specialist Wake County Environmental Services www.wakegov.com/health About 85 to 90% of us will be infected with chicken pox (varicella zoster virus) in our lifetime. Once infected, the virus can lie dormant for 20-25 years before showing up again (95% of the time) as shingles (zoster). Most people won’t notice a difference between both, and there is no way to tell the difference without lab testing. Shingles is an infection that can spread to other family members in the workplace. The question of when to exclude an employee from the clinic work area is complicated. The good news is most of your employees may not even get shingles and they can be kept/stayed at work as long as they are well. The tingling and itching that comes in the pre-pimple stage is contagious but the pink flat bumps are not. Anyone infected with shingles who is able to wear a mask can continue to come in until the lesions start oozing; at that point an employee should stay home. The high likelihood of recurrence of shingles virus in your customers with a compromised immune system puts you in a bit of a difficult position. You will need to balance the contagiousness of the virus against the health risks of aggravation of the customer’s primary condition. Having the conversation with your customers because “it could be a professional courtesy” is not enough. They should be told a precise timeline of when they would pose a greater risk to their system. If your state’s regulation requires vaccination of your employees, it is highly recommended that you ask for evidence of a full vaccination; at least two shots with 30 days between immunizations. This would reduce the risk in both families. For additional information:

Question: What is the reason that there is so little research being done to help to investigate causes and to find a cure for Antiphosoholipid Syndrome?

Must_have: The rarity of Antiphospholipid Syndrome leads to less focus from researchers and lesser funding, which contributes to what may appear as 'limited' research.
Nice_to_have: Despite these challenges, there are researchers dedicated to investigating and finding potential cures for the Antiphospholipid Syndrome.
Many rare diseases face similar challenges in research funding and focus.

Question: Are confusion and facial itch possible side effects of methadone?
Free_form_answer: The major hazards of methadone are respiratory depression and, to a lesser degree, systemic hypotension. Respiratory arrest, shock, cardiac arrest, and death have occurred.
Must_have: Confusion is indeed a possible side effect of methadone.
Methadone may also cause an itchy rash, which could potentially affect the face.
It's crucial to note that both of these side effects should prompt immediate medical attention.
Nice_to_have: Among other potential side effects of methadone are lightheadedness, dizziness, sedation, nausea, vomiting, and sweating.
These effects usually decrease over time with prolonged administration of methadone.
The major hazards associated with methadone include respiratory depression, cardiac complications, and even death in severe cases.

Methadone is a long-lasting opiate used to relieve chronic pain. It belongs to a group of drugs called opioid agonists, which block pain signals in the brain. Methadone can also suppress the symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Methadone is safe and effective when used as prescribed. Unfortunately, too much methadone can be dangerous. However, methadone side effects can range from mild to severe. This article goes over potential side effects associated with methadone and how to manage them. What are methadone side effects? The FDA approved methadone in 1972 to treat acute, moderate, or severe pain, including chronic cancer pain. Its use was later expanded to treat opioid use disorder. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) classifies methadone as a Schedule II Tela prescription drug. The DEA includes methadone on this list due to its high-risk potential for abuse. You should never share methadone with someone else and do not attempt to use it recreationally. Three key things to know before taking methadone are: * Talk to your doctor: If you are taking opioid medications for pain, including codeine and hydrocodone, discuss with your doctor on starting methadone treatment. * Seek a treatment facility: Methadone isn’t meant to be taken at home. You can get methadone at clinic sites and local programs that specialize in opioid addiction. * Ask your doc about treatment options: You can get methadone in 3 different ways: in the form of a pill, liquid taken by mouth, or injected. There are many methadone treatment centers in the United States. They use methadone to prevent and treat addiction to heroin, prescription pain medicines, and other opioids. Is methadone addictive? Yes, methadone is an addictive opioid. Do not stop taking methadone abruptly because you could experience withdrawal symptoms when doing so. Unmanaged withdrawal can include flu-like symptoms, nausea, vomiting, and anxiety. Methadone precautions Your dose of methadone and the length of your treatment varies on if you are taking methadone for pain or opioid use disorder (OUD). Your licensed healthcare professional will determine the right methadone dose for you. Methadone risks can increase when it’s combined with other medications, substances, or medical conditions. It’s crucial to keep the following in mind when taking this medication.

Question: What is methylprednisolone and how does it affect the body?
Free_form_answer: Methylprednisolone, a corticosteroid, is similar to a natural hormone produced by your adrenal glands. It is often used to replace this chemical when your body does not make enough of it. It relieves inflammation (swelling, heat, redness, and pain) and is used to treat certain forms of arthritis; skin, blood, kidney, eye, thyroid, and intestinal disorders (e.g., colitis); severe allergies; and asthma. Methylprednisolone is also used to treat certain types of cancer. This medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.
Must_have: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid similar to a hormone produced by the adrenal glands.
It is used to replace this hormone when the body does not produce enough of it.
It is used for treating certain forms of arthritis, skin, blood, kidney, eye, thyroid, and intestinal disorders, severe allergies, asthma, and certain types of cancer.
Nice_to_have: Methylprednisolone helps in relieving inflammation that includes swelling, heat, redness, and pain.
This medication can also be prescribed for other uses, so for further uses, consult your doctor or pharmacist.

Methylprednisolone works by blocking the production of certain chemicals in the body that cause inflammation. This can help to reduce swelling, pain, and other symptoms associated with conditions such as arthritis, asthma, and allergies. It can also be used to treat certain types of cancer, as well as to suppress the immune system in people who are undergoing organ transplants.

Methylprednisolone is available in several forms, including tablets, injections, and topical creams. It is typically taken for a short period of time, as long-term use can lead to serious side effects. These can include weight gain, high blood pressure, and an increased risk of infection.

Overall, methylprednisolone is a powerful medication that can be used to treat a variety of conditions. However, it is important to use it as directed by a healthcare provider and to be aware of the potential side effects.

Question: Why should Simvastatin be taken in the evening, rather than morning?
Free_form_answer: Simvastatin comes as a tablet to take by mouth. It usually is taken once a day in the evening. Take simvastatin at around the same time every day.
Must_have: Simvastatin works by inhibiting an enzyme involved in cholesterol production that is most active at night, hence it should be taken in the evening.

Question: How long does prednisone stay in the body after discontinuation of the medication after a tapering of dosage. Are chills, fever and abdominal pain common when discontinuing this drug? Is there anything else we should know?
Free_form_answer: If you abruptly stop taking prednisone or taper off too quickly, you might experience prednisone withdrawal symptoms:
Must_have: Prednisone withdrawal symptoms may include severe fatigue, weakness, body aches, and joint pain.
Prednisone is similar to cortisol, a hormone naturally produced by the adrenal glands.
When prednisone is taken for more than a few weeks, the adrenal glands may decrease in their production of cortisol.
A gradual reduction in the dosage of prednisone can allow the adrenal glands to resume their normal function.
The time it takes to taper off prednisone can depend on the disease being treated, the dosage, duration of use, and other medical considerations.
A full recovery can take a week to several months.
If prednisone withdrawal symptoms are experienced while tapering off the drug, a doctor should be contacted.
Nice_to_have: Chills, fever, and abdominal pain are not commonly reported as symptoms of prednisone withdrawal, however, individual experiences can vary and these symptoms should not be ignored.
If such symptoms are experienced, it would be prudent to contact a healthcare provider.
They will be able to provide appropriate advice based on the specific circumstances and overall health condition.

Question: Can electrical high voltage shock cause swallowing difficulty?
Free_form_answer: An electrical injury is damage to the skin or internal organs when a person comes into direct contact with an electrical current. Symptoms may include: Changes in alertness (consciousness) Broken bones Heart attack (chest, arm, neck, jaw, or back pain) Headache Problems with swallowing, vision, or hearing Irregular heartbeat Muscle spasms and pain Numbness or tingling Breathing problems or lung failure Seizures Skin burns
Must_have: After a high voltage electrical shock, symptoms and complications can vary widely depending on numerous factors including the intensity of the shock and the pathway it took through the body.
Immediate medical attention is crucial if someone experiences a high voltage electrical shock, as some complications might not be immediately obvious.
Swallowing difficulties can be one of the potential complications following an electrical injury.
Nice_to_have: Symptoms and potential complications of an electrical shock can be as varied as changes in consciousness, broken bones, heart issues, headache, vision and hearing impairment, muscle spasms and pain, numbness or tingling, breathing difficulties, seizures, and skin burns.
Personal health status can also influence the severity of the complications from an electrical shock.

Question: I want information on Schmorl's nodes.
Free_form_answer: Schmorl nodes, also referred as intravertebral disc herniations, refer to protrusions of the cartilage of the intervertebral disc through the vertebral body endplate and into the adjacent vertebra. The protrusions may contact the marrow of the vertebra, leading to inflammation. Schmorl nodes can be asymptomatic, meaning they do not cause any symptoms, or they can cause back pain, particularly during the teen years and young adulthood. They are often found in people who perform heavy physical work, such as lifting.Schmorl nodes can be detected through radiologic testing like X-rays, CT scans or MRIs and are considered a common finding in spinal imaging. The diagnosis needs to be differentiated from other causes of back pain. The treatment for Schmorl nodes typically focuses on managing symptoms, and it often involves physical therapy and pain relieving medications.In extreme cases where the Schmorl nodes are large or cause severe symptoms, surgical intervention could be considered, but this is rare.
Must_have: Treatment typically focuses on managing symptoms and can involve physical therapy and pain relieving medications.
If Schmorl's nodes become large or cause inflammation in the vertebra, they can cause back pain and stiffness.
Schmorl's nodes, also known as intravertebral disc herniations, occur when the cartilage of the intervertebral disc protrudes through the vertebral body endplate into the adjacent vertebra.
Schmorl's nodes are protrusions of the intervertebral disc cartilage through the vertebral body endplate and into the adjacent vertebra.
They often do not cause symptoms and are usually discovered during spine X-rays performed for other reasons.
Nice_to_have: Surgery is rarely required for Schmorl's nodes and is usually only considered if conservative treatments have been unsuccessful in managing chronic, debilitating pain.
Treatment for Schmorl's nodes often involves nonsurgical methods, including pain medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications.
Schmorl nodes can cause back pain, particularly during the teen years and young adulthood, and are often found in people who carry out heavy physical labor.
If the nodes are large or cause severe symptoms, surgical intervention may be considered, but this is a rare occurrence.

It could also, in rare cases, be a symptom of a neurological disorder such as narcolepsy.In such situations, seeking evaluation by a healthcare provider is recommended to determine a possible underlying condition and develop a treatment plan.

In rare cases, sleep paralysis could be a symptom of neurological disorders like narcolepsy.

Question: WHAT exercises can I do, safely, with asthma?
Free_form_answer: Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), also called exercise-induced asthma, is a narrowing of the airways in the lungs that is triggered by physical activity.
Must_have: Patients with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) are typically sensitive to low temperatures and dry air.
Symptoms of EIB include wheezing, a tight chest, coughing, shortness of breath, and rarely, chest pain.
Warm-weather activities and those requiring only short bursts of energy such as hiking, baseball, golf, walking and leisure biking are less likely to trigger symptoms.
Nice_to_have: Individuals with EIB should avoid sports like cross-country skiing, running, soccer, basketball and hockey, as these activities require continuous exertion and could exacerbate symptoms.
Other triggers for EIB include air pollutants, high pollen levels, and viral respiratory infections.
Even the sport you choose can affect your symptoms.
Swimming is less likely to cause asthma symptoms because the warm, humid environment of the pool does not aggravate the airways.

Question: Define a Branch Bundle Block, it's symptoms and known treatments.
Free_form_answer: Bundle branch block is a condition in which there's a delay or obstruction along the pathway that electrical impulses travel to make your heart beat. The delay or blockage may occur on the pathway that sends electrical impulses to the left or the right side of the bottom chambers (ventricles) of your heart.
Must_have: Bundle branch block is a condition with a delay or blockage along the pathway that electrical impulses travel to make the heart beat.
It can affect the pathway to either the left or the right side of the heart's ventricles.
There is no specific treatment for the bundle branch block itself, but underlying conditions such as heart disease must be treated.
Symptoms, although not commonly present, can include fainting or feeling like fainting.
Nice_to_have: Bundle branch block can sometimes make it harder for the heart to pump blood efficiently.
Many people who have bundle branch block are unaware that they have this condition.
sample_predictions:
Answer:

Step 1/2
1. What is a Branch Bundle Block? A Branch Bundle Block (BBB) is a type of heart block that occurs when the electrical signals from the heart's upper chambers (atria) are blocked from reaching the lower chambers (ventricles) through the bundle of His and the bundle branches. This can lead to a slow or irregular heartbeat, which can cause symptoms such as dizziness, fainting, and shortness of breath.

Step 2/2
2. What are the symptoms of a Branch Bundle Block? The symptoms of a Branch Bundle Block can vary depending on the severity of the block. Some common symptoms include: - Dizziness - Fainting - Shortness of breath - Chest pain - Palpitations - Fatigue - Weakness - Syncope (loss of consciousness) - Bradycardia (slow heart rate) - Tachycardia (fast heart rate) - Heart failure - Arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats) - Sudden cardiac death (in severe cases) 3. What are the known treatments for a Branch Bundle Block? The treatment for a Branch Bundle Block depends on the severity of the block and the patient's symptoms. Some common treatments include: - Medication: Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and antiarrhythmic drugs can be used to slow down the heart rate and improve the electrical conduction through the heart. - Pacemaker: A pacemaker is a small device that is implanted under the skin and sends electrical signals to the heart to maintain a regular heartbeat. - Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): An ICD is a device that is implanted under the skin and monitors the heart's electrical activity. If it detects an abnormal heartbeat, it can deliver a shock to restore a normal rhythm. - Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be necessary to repair or replace damaged heart tissue or to correct structural abnormalities that are causing the block. Overall, the treatment for a Branch Bundle Block is aimed at restoring a normal heart rhythm and preventing serious complications such as heart failure or sudden cardiac death. It is important to work closely with a healthcare provider to determine the best treatment plan for each individual patient.

Question: If a person is allergic to Penicillin, is he likely to be allergic to Cephalexin also?
Free_form_answer: Administration of cephalothin, cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cefazolin in penicillin-allergic patients is associated with a significant increase in the rate of allergic reactions; whereas administration of cefprozil, cefuroxime, cefpodoxime, ceftazidime, and ceftriaxone is not.
Must_have: Patients who are allergic to penicillin have a risk of allergic reactions to cephalexin.
Although not guaranteed, because both drugs are part of the beta-lactam antibiotics family and share a similar structure, allergic reactions could potentially be triggered.
Patients with penicillin allergy should always inform their healthcare provider before taking any new medication, including cephalexin.
Nice_to_have: Cephalothin, cephalexin, cefadroxil, and cefazolin, in particular, have been associated with a higher rate of allergic reactions in penicillin-allergic patients when compared to cefprozil, cefuroxime, cefpodoxime, ceftazidime, and ceftriaxone.
sample_predictions: Cephalexin is a type of antibiotic called a cephalosporin. It is used to treat a variety of bacterial infections. Cephalexin is similar to penicillin in that it is a beta-lactam antibiotic. However, cephalexin is not derived from penicillin and is not related to penicillin in terms of its chemical structure. Therefore, a person who is allergic to penicillin is not likely to be allergic to cephalexin. However, it is always important to inform your healthcare provider of any allergies you have before taking any medication.

Question: What is the success rate of heart ablation? Can arrhythmia occur after ablation?
Free_form_answer: Cardiac ablation carries a risk of complications, including:
Must_have: Cardiac ablation has risks, including bleeding or infection at the catheter site, damage to blood vessels, puncture of the heart, damage to heart valves, damage to the electrical system of the heart possibly requiring a pacemaker, blood clots, stroke or heart attack, narrowing of veins between lungs and heart, damage to kidneys from dye used in procedure, and in rare cases, death.
Nice_to_have: Arrhythmia can occur after a heart ablation, as damage to the heart's electrical system during the procedure could worsen the arrhythmia.
While cardiac ablation can be successful in treating many serious heart rhythm disturbances, it's not always successful, and in some cases, arrhythmias can recur.
Overall, the success rate varies depending on the type and complexity of the arrhythmia, the specific details of the individual's heart disease, and other comorbidities.
Studies have reported success rates ranging from 60% to 90% for various types of arrhythmias.
Despite the potential risks, many people benefit greatly from this procedure.
It's important to talk to your healthcare provider about the potential benefits and risks of cardiac ablation.
sample_predictions: The success rate of heart ablation is about 70%. Arrhythmia can occur after ablation, but it is usually not serious and can be treated with medication.

Nice_to_have: Exercise can potentially help manage some of the symptoms associated with NPH, though specific exercises should be discussed with a healthcare provider.
Support groups can be beneficial for individuals with NPH, which can offer an opportunity to connect with others facing similar challenges.
Online community portals and free webinars can provide resources and comprehensive information about the condition.
However, it is important to consult with your healthcare provider before making any major changes to your lifestyle, treatment plan or exercise routine.

Hydrocephalus

Hydrocephalus is a syndrome characterized by an enlarged head and progressive impaired mental, motor, and sensory function. It usually occurs in children and is a national public health problem, requiring early diagnosis and treatment. If hydrocephalus is not treated early, the child may suffer severe disability and/or blindness or other forms of regression, including death.

Incidence

The age at which hydrocephalus typically manifests in childhood is the birth to one year age group. * The worldwide population prevalence rate is 2.2 per 1000. * The prevalence rate in Kenyan children is 14.1 per 1000, and 4.6 per 1000 in Shamsian children. * In Sub-Saharan populations is 5.8 to 10.1 per 1000. This rate is the highest in the world. In Mozambique the prevalence rate is 28 children per 1000 of African ethnicity children. In Liberia the rate is 53.9 per 1000. The Caucasians in these countries have a very low prevalence rate. * In other countries, hydrocephalus may be under-recognized, and the global prevalence rate of hydrocephalus may be as high as 20 per 1000 (Vingerhoets and Christophe, undated). * The rate in the Asia Pacific region is increasing. * In Thailand, hydrocephalus prevalence in children is 2.6 to 10.7 per 1000. * Hydrocephalus prevalence in Central and Western Africa is higher in boys than girls. This is the exception in the other parts of the world where hydrocephalus is comparable in both sexes. * In Sub-Saharan countries, hydrocephalus has lower prevalence rates compared to the Northern, Western, and Eastern African countries. * The rate in Sub-Saharan countries is 1.9 per 1000. In Sub-Saharan countries, there is widespread inequality in treatment of this disease. There are vast disparities in the provision of treatment in high income, as compared to the low-income countries. Over 10 million children live with hydrocephalus each year, with up to 2,000- 3,000 pediatric neurosurgeons

Question: Can low dose naltrexone be used to treat severe depression?
Free_form_answer: The purpose of this pilot study is to determine if taking a low dose of naltrexone in addition to an antidepressant medication can help treat relapse or recurrence in people with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved naltrexone for the treatment of alcohol dependence and opioid dependence, but the FDA has not approved naltrexone to treat depression. The investigators hypothesize that patients with breakthrough depression on an antidepressant regimen containing a pro-dopaminergic agent assigned to treatment with low dose naltrexone will demonstrate higher rates of response compared to those patients taking placebo.
Must_have: The FDA has approved naltrexone for the treatment of alcohol dependence and opioid dependence, but it is not FDA-approved for the treatment of depression.
The efficacy of low dose naltrexone as an adjunct treatment for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is still under study.
Nice_to_have: A pilot study is being conducted to determine the potential effectiveness of low dose naltrexone in treating relapse or recurrence in people with Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) who are already on an antidepressant regimen.
The hypothesis is that those given low dose naltrexone might show higher rates of response compared to those taking a placebo.

During the treatment development phase, researchers previously have studied LDN to treat depression. However, more robust, large scale studies are needed to support its use, In the new study, researchers involved 91 participants with severe treatment-resistant depression. All participants had engagement difficulties and long-lasting, severe symptoms before entering the study. However, none of the participants had displayed suicidal tendencies. Each participant was randomly assigned to either a LDN group or an inactive placebo therapy group. The study group received 4.5 mg of LDN once daily and the placebo group received no drug intervention. At the start of the intervention, participants were assessed several times on a scale called the Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS). The MADRS is used to measure the severity of depressive symptoms, ranging from zero to a maximum of 51. At the conclusion of the nine-week study, an analysis revealed no significant difference between the two groups. However, a subgroup analysis did find that participants who were diagnosed with late-onset depression who received the LDN intervention responded to treatment. Six of the 14 participants with late-onset depression who received the LDN treatment had a 61 percent reduction in the severity of their depression after nine weeks. One participant’s symptoms completely subsided. The researchers revealed that the positive benefits they observed in the late-onset group may be due to LDN’s influence on the development of the microbiome, which plays a critical role in the functioning of the brain. “We need more studies to confirm this finding,” acknowledged the study’s lead author Prof. Alvarado, professor of psychiatry at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, MA, and the Menninger Coordinator for Functional Genomics at The Menninger Clinic in Houston, TX. “It should be noted that more people with late onset depression have more symptoms that are harder to treat.” Prior research also has supported the use of LDN to treat autism spectrum disorder, reducing the severity of symptoms in more than half of the patients. Similarly, because researchers have suggested brain inflammation plays a role in the onset and progression of autism, future studies might include an examination of the brain’s inflammatory processes to better understand the LDN mechanism. Although serious side effects to LDN have not been reported, researchers note in their paper that certain adverse effects of the treatment have been noted in prior studies of the medication, including weight loss, chills, and flushing in the extremities.

Low dose naltrexone (LDN) is a relatively new way to treat cancer pain, lupus symptoms, fibromyalgia, MS symptoms, depression, and other disorders. LDN is a type of opioid antagonist that’s similar to naltrexone. It binds to opioid receptors in the brain, causing a reduction in the amount of natural opioids in the body. Naltrexone can be used to treat opioid addictions, but LDN is different. LDN doesn’t prevent the release of opioids (natural substances that act as an analgesic) in the body, it just blocks their receptors. LDN also increases the production of other natural opioids in the body. This means that people who take LDN can receive the benefits of opioids without dealing with the negative side effects. Since LDN affects the brain and body, it stands to reason that it can help with mental disorders like mood disorders. But how does LDN work exactly? Let’s find out.

How does low dose naltrexone work?

By now, you know that LDN blocks opioid receptors. But what does that mean? The brain uses opioids to regulate the nervous system, emotional responses, and self-regulation. These drugs act in your brain (more specifically, the hypothalamus) to reduce reactions to pain, regulate your emotions, and help with anxiety. While opioids are natural pain-inhibitors, they can quickly become addictive when abused. This is why it’s crucial to monitor the use of opioids. LDN is a non-addictive alternative that will continue to trigger the calming and soothing emotional effects of opioids without any risk of addiction. So why does LDN work for people with low moods? Well, the theory goes that LDN acts as a mood stabilizer. This is because LDN increases the production of endorphins, which regulates mood. Research has found that naltrexone can decrease symptoms of mental illness. Researchers suggest that LDN could make a difference for people with mental illnesses. Basically, LDN makes it easier for your brain to manage the complex connections between emotions and pain. Studies have even found that LDN can relieve the symptoms of depression. As with any prescription medication, it’s important to discuss its use with a licensed medical doctor.

Question: What is hepatitis and how is it transmitted?
Free_form_answer: Scientists have identified 5 unique hepatitis viruses, identified by the letters A, B, C, D, and E. While all cause liver disease, they vary in important ways.
Must_have: Hepatitis is transmitted through various ways depending on the type: Hepatitis A is transmitted through consumption of contaminated water or food or through certain sex practices; Hepatitis B and C are mainly transmitted through exposure to infective blood, semen, and other body fluids, through transfusions of contaminated blood, contaminated injections during medical procedures, and through injection drug use; Hepatitis D occurs only in those already infected with Hepatitis B; Hepatitis E is mainly transmitted through consumption of contaminated water or food.
Nice_to_have: All five types of hepatitis cause liver diseases, however, their severity can vary.
Vaccines are available to prevent Hepatitis A, B, and E, however, no vaccine is available for Hepatitis C. Hepatitis D only occurs in those already infected with Hepatitis B.
Hepatitis E is a common cause of hepatitis outbreaks in developing parts of the world but is increasingly recognized as an important cause of disease in developed countries.
Vaccines to prevent Hepatitis E infection have been developed but are not widely available.

Question: Are small lumps around the scrotum a symptom of Jock Itch?
Free_form_answer: Jock itch usually stays around the creases of the upper thigh and does not involve the scrotum or penis. Jock itch may spread to the anus, causing anal itching and discomfort. Question: What causes rib cage pain? How is it remedied?
Free_form_answer: Ribcage pain may be caused by any of the following: Bruised, cracked, or fractured rib Inflammation of cartilage near the breastbone (costochondritis) Osteoporosis Pleurisy (the pain is worse when breathing deeply) Rest and not moving the area (immobilization) are the best cures for a ribcage fracture.
Must_have: The causes of rib cage pain may include a bruised, cracked, or fractured rib, inflammation of the cartilage near the breastbone (costochondritis), osteoporosis, or pleurisy.
The best remedies for a rib cage fracture would be rest and immobilization.
It's important to follow your healthcare provider's instructions for treating the cause of ribcage pain.
Nice_to_have: Seeking professional medical advice is highly recommended if ribcage pain persists, as the underlying cause may need a thorough evaluation.
The cause of rib cage pain may vary from person to person and could involve skeletal issues, muscle strain, or underlying diseases.

Fat
The pain is referred to the rib cage by the diaphragmatic nerves and results from the inflammation or irritation of the fat under the coat. The skin on the rib cage (and on the underside of the sternum) contains many apocrine glands. When the dog is excited or scared they start producing large quantities of fat. Sometimes, the fat encircles the skin around the ribs as an external mass. It is a soft, sausage-shaped mass of fat. They can easily be removed by severing the muscle from the ribs with some light suction or a needle, which sucks the fat out. The usual methods of removal are cold compresses or acupuncture. The fatality rate despite aggressive medical intervention indicates the severity of this disease.

Question: Is there always an elevated temperature associated with appendicitis?
Free_form_answer: A blockage inside of the appendix causes appendicitis. The blockage leads to increased pressure, problems with blood flow, and inflammation. If the blockage is not treated, the appendix can burst and spread infection into the abdomen. This causes a condition called peritonitis. The main symptom is pain in the abdomen, often on the right side. It is usually sudden and gets worse over time. Other symptoms may include Swelling in the abdomen Loss of appetite Nausea and vomiting Constipation or diarrhea Inability to pass gas Low fever Not everyone with appendicitis has all these symptoms.
Must_have: Not every patient with appendicitis experiences an elevated temperature.
The main symptom of appendicitis is abdominal pain, usually on the right side, which tends to get worse over time.
Other potential symptoms can include swelling in the abdomen, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea and the inability to pass gas.
Nice_to_have: Appendicitis is caused by a blockage in the appendix which leads to increased pressure, blood flow issues, and inflammation.
Untreated blockage may result in the appendix bursting and spreading infection into the abdomen, leading to a condition called peritonitis.
However, these symptoms can vary and not everyone with appendicitis will display all of these symptoms.

Question: What its the efficacy of administering Gabamentine and hydrocodone together and are there any interactions?
Free_form_answer: 1. Coadministration of NEURONTIN with hydrocodone decreases hydrocodone exposure [see CLINICAL PHARMACOLOGY (12.3)]. The potential for alteration in hydrocodone exposure and effect should be considered when NEURONTIN is started or discontinued in a patient taking hydrocodone. 2. Coadministration of NEURONTIN (125 to 500 mg; N=48) decreases hydrocodone (10 mg; N=50) C max and AUC values in a dose-dependent manner relative to administration of hydrocodone alone; C max and AUC values are 3% to 4% lower, respectively, after administration of 125 mg NEURONTIN and 21% to 22% lower, respectively, after administration of 500 mg NEURONTIN. The mechanism for this interaction is unknown. Hydrocodone increases gabapentin AUC values by 14%. The magnitude of interaction at other doses is not known.
Must_have: The administration of Gabapentin (Neurontin) and Hydrocodone simultaneously can decrease the exposure of hydrocodone.
The dosage of Gabapentin affects the extent of this decrease, 125 mg results in 3% to 4% lower hydrocodone exposure and 500 mg results in 21% to 22% lower exposure.
Gabapentin's interaction with Hydrocodone is unknown.
Hydrocodone increases Gabapentin's AUC (Area Under Curve) values by 14%.
Nice_to_have: The change of exposure should be considered when starting or discontinuing the use of Gabapentin in a patient taking Hydrocodone.
The magnitude of interaction at other doses of Gabapentin and Hydrocodone is still unknown.
A conversation with the healthcare provider may be necessary to discuss the benefits and risks of coadministration.

Question: The question concerns drug interactions such as the safety of taking Diclofenac with Isinopril or other NSAIDs.
Free_form_answer: Avoid Concomitant Use of NSAIDsRegarding the combination of diclofenac and lisinopril, caution is advised. Diclofenac, like other NSAIDs, may affect the excretion of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors like lisinopril. This interaction could lead to increased blood pressure, decreased kidney function, or increased levels of potassium in the blood. It is recommended to monitor blood pressure, kidney function regularly, and electrolyte levels during concurrent use of these medications.
Must_have: Diclofenac may affect the excretion of ACE inhibitors like lisinopril, potentially leading to increased blood pressure, decreased kidney function or increased potassium levels.
Regular monitoring of blood pressure, kidney function and electrolyte levels is recommended when these medicines are used together.
Nice_to_have: Caution is advised when combining diclofenac and lisinopril.

Question: Is trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) progressive and how is it diagnosed?
Free_form_answer: Trisomy 13, also called Patau syndrome, is a chromosomal condition associated with severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities in many parts of the body. Individuals with trisomy 13 often have heart defects, brain or spinal cord abnormalities, very small or poorly developed eyes (microphthalmia), extra fingers or toes, an opening in the lip (a cleft lip) with or without an opening in the roof of the mouth (a cleft palate), and weak muscle tone (hypotonia). Due to the presence of several life-threatening medical problems, many infants with trisomy 13 die within their first days or weeks of life. Only five percent to 10 percent of children with this condition live past their first year. Trisomy 13 is not progressive; instead, it is a congenital condition that is present from birth.Diagnosis of trisomy 13 is usually made based on clinical examination at birth due to the presence of numerous physical abnormalities. In addition, prenatal screening can detect the presence of trisomy 13, including noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT), and diagnostic tests such as amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling (CVS). High-resolution ultrasound is also used during pregnancy to detect physical characteristics symptomatic of trisomy 13. For a definitive diagnosis, a karyotype - a test that evaluates the number and structure of a person's chromosomes - is done, which can identify the third copy of chromosome 13 that causes trisomy 13.
Must_have: Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is present at birth and not progressive.
Diagnosis of trisomy 13 usually involves clinical examination at birth, prenatal screening, and a karyotype test to identify the extra copy of chromosome 13.
Nice_to_have: Symptoms for Trisomy 13 often include heart defects, brain or spinal cord abnormalities, very small or poorly developed eyes (microphthalmia), extra fingers or toes, an opening in the lip (cleft lip) with or without a cleft palate, and weak muscle tone (hypotonia).
Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT), high-resolution ultrasound during pregnancy, and diagnostic tests like amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling can also aid in the diagnosis of trisomy 13.

Question: What is the recommended treatment and prevention protocol for mite infestation in humans?
Free_form_answer: When a person is infested with scabies mites the first time, symptoms may not appear for up to two months after being infested. However, an infested person can transmit scabies, even if they do not have symptoms. Scabies usually is passed by direct, prolonged skin-to-skin contact with an infested person. However, a person with crusted (Norwegian) scabies can spread the infestation by brief skin-to-skin contact or by exposure to bedding, clothing, or even furniture that he/she has used.
Must_have: Scabies, a condition characterized by an infestation of mites, is usually spread via direct, prolonged skin-to-skin contact with infected individuals or through exposure to infested clothing, bedding or furniture.
Medical treatment for scabies is typically advised for individuals who live in the same household as the infected individual.
In order to prevent reinfestation, all household members and other potentially exposed individuals should be treated simultaneously along with the infested person.

Items such as clothing or bedding that have been in close proximity to the infested individual within the past three days should be thoroughly laundered using hot water and hot dryer cycles, or dry-cleaned.
Those with crusted scabies and their close contacts should be treated quickly and intensively to prevent outbreaks.
Nice_to_have: When an individual is infected with scabies for the first time, symptoms may not appear for up to two months.
Nonetheless, they remain contagions, even without symptoms.
To prevent scabies, one should avoid skin-to-skin contact with infested individuals or with items used by them.
Infested items that cannot be laundered or dry cleaned can be disinfected by sealing them in a plastic bag for up to a week.
After treatment, children and adults can typically return to daycare, school, or work.
For those with crusted scabies, it is recommended that the rooms they have used be cleaned and vacuumed thoroughly for prevention of further outbreaks.

Question: What causes Hypoglycemia in newborns and is there a way for a pregnant woman to avoid giving birth to a child with Hypoglycemia?
Free_form_answer: Babies need blood sugar (glucose) for energy. Most of that glucose is used by the brain.
Must_have: Neonatal hypoglycemia occurs when the newborn's blood glucose level is below a safe level for the baby's age, causing symptoms.

Risk factors for hypoglycemia in newborns include being born early, having a serious infection, needing oxygen right after delivery, having a mother with diabetes, having slower than usual growth in the womb during pregnancy, and being smaller in size than normal for their gestational age.
A pregnant woman with diabetes must work closely with her healthcare provider to control her blood sugar level to reduce the risk of her baby developing hypoglycemia.
Nice_to_have: Most of the glucose in a baby's body is used by the brain.
Before birth, a baby receives glucose from the mother through the placenta, and after birth, a baby gets glucose from the mother's milk or formula, and also produces it in the liver.

The baby's glucose levels can drop if there's too much insulin in the blood, the baby isn't producing enough glucose, the baby's body is using more glucose than is being produced, or the baby isn't feeding enough to keep the glucose level up.
It's important that a newborn's blood sugar level is monitored after birth, especially if the mother has diabetes or there were other risk factors present.
Neonatal hypoglycemia occurs in about 1 to 3 out of every 1,000 births.

Question: Can a CT scan detect diverticulitis or diverticulosis?
Free_form_answer: CT scan: This radiology test takes multiple cross-sectional pictures of the body. It is not generally performed to make a diagnosis of diverticulosis, but this type of exam, when done for other reasons, may identify diverticula.
Must_have: A CT scan is not generally used to diagnose diverticulosis, but it may incidentally identify diverticula.
A CT scan is highly useful in diagnosing diverticulitis and identifying complications related to diverticulitis such as abscesses, perforations, or fistulas.
Nice_to_have: A CT scan employs multiple cross-sectional imaging to visualize the internal structures of the body.
Despite diverticulosis may not be its primary focus for diagnostics, it can still detect its presence when done for other reasons.
For a detailed view of the potential complications of diverticulitis, a CT scan is typically recommended.

Question: Could someone who did not get vaccinated for measles in childhood develop SSPE anytime in adulthood?
Free_form_answer: Very few cases are seen in the U.S. since the nationwide measles vaccination program. SSPE tends to occur several years after a person has measles, even though the person seems to have fully recovered from the illness. Males are more often affected than females. The disease generally occurs in children and adolescents.
Must_have: SSPE (subacute sclerosing panencephalitis) is a very rare, but fatal disease of the central nervous system that is a late complication of a measles infection.
It typically occurs several years after a person has had measles, even if they seem to have completely recovered from the illness.
Nice_to_have: SSPE tends to affect children and adolescents, with males more often affected than females.

However, it is important to note that measles vaccination significantly reduces the occurrence of SSPE, and in countries with strong nationwide measles vaccination programs, such as the U.S., very few cases of SSPE are seen.

While SSPE generally occurs in children and adolescents, if an individual did not get vaccinated for measles in childhood and contracted measles, the risk to develop SSPE would persist into adulthood.

Question: What are the most current findings regarding causation, treatment and therapy for children with Kippel-Tranaunay-Syndrome (KTS)?
Free_form_answer: Supportive care for Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
Must_have: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome may require wearing compression garments to reduce pain, swelling and to protect the limb.
In the case of differing leg lengths, a heel insert may be utilized to aid in walking.
As a precaution against blood clots, anticoagulant therapy may be required.
For excessively large foot or leg, an orthopedic surgeon may reshape the limb, halt growth, or remove problematic veins.
Debulking, sclerotherapy, and laser therapy are other potential surgical interventions.
Nice_to_have: Pain medications and antibiotics may also be part of the treatment.
In some circumstances, doctors may recommend an injection of an irritating solution to collapse the abnormal veins.
Pulsed dye laser treatments can be used to lighten the capillary malformation (port wine stain) and speed healing if the lesion begins to bleed.

Question: What is the treatment for someone who thinks he has taken an overdose of Iron pills?
Must_have: If someone has taken an overdose of Iron pills, it is essential to call the local emergency services or the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222).
An overdose of iron pills can be particularly dangerous for children.
This information should not be used in place of seeking professional medical help in the event of an actual overdose.
Nice_to_have: The information needed when calling the emergency services in the event of an overdose includes the person's age, weight, and condition, the name of the product (including ingredients and strength if known), the time it was swallowed, the amount swallowed, and if the medicine was prescribed for the person.
It would also be beneficial to remember that iron overdose can occur if someone takes more than the normal or recommended amount of the mineral, whether accidentally or intentionally.

Low potassium levels can lead to muscle weakness, cramping, and fatigue, while high potassium levels can lead to heart rhythm disturbances and other serious health problems. Question: What is the likelihood that a person with hereditary rickets will pass it to his or her child?
Free_form_answer: Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can have several patterns of inheritance. When the condition results from mutations in the PHEX gene, it is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. The PHEX gene is located on the X chromosome, which is one of the two sex chromosomes. In females (who have two X chromosomes), a mutation in one of the two copies of the gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. In males (who have only one X chromosome), a mutation in the only copy of the gene in each cell causes the disorder. Less commonly, hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can have an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. This form of the condition is often called Dent disease. Like the PHEX gene, the gene associated with Dent disease is located on the X chromosome. In males, one altered copy of the gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition. In females, a mutation would have to occur in both copies of the gene to cause the disorder. Because it is unlikely that females will have two altered copies of this gene, males are affected by X-linked recessive disorders much more frequently than females. In a few families, hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets has had an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, which means one copy of an altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. The rare condition HHRH has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means both copies of a gene in each cell have mutations.
Must_have: Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can have different patterns of inheritance, including X-linked dominant, X-linked recessive, and autosomal dominant and recessive.
The mutation in the PHEX gene on the X chromosome leads to the disorder in both males and females.
However, males are more frequently affected than females in X-linked recessive disorders, such as Dent disease.
Nice_to_have: In females, a mutation would have to occur in both copies of the gene to cause hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets.
In a few families, hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets has had an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
The rare condition HHRH has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.

The exact cause of fibromyalgia is unknown, but it is thought to be related to changes in the way the brain processes pain signals.

There is no cure for fibromyalgia, but there are treatments that can help manage the symptoms. These include medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes.

If you think you may have fibromyalgia, talk to your doctor. They can help you develop a treatment plan that is right for you.

There is no single test that can diagnose fibromyalgia. Instead, doctors use a combination of tests and exams to rule out other conditions that may be causing the symptoms.

* medications, such as antidepressants or anti-seizure medications
* physical therapy
* lifestyle changes, such as getting regular exercise and managing stress

If you have fibromyalgia, it is important to talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of treatment.
