Question: What is your position on Homozygout MTHFR A1298C (a genetic change) Issues and long term prognosis?
Free_form_answer: MTHFR gene mutation is a genetic change that affects an enzyme involved in breaking down the amino acid homocysteine.[1][2][3] C677T and A1298C are two very common MTHFR gene changes.
Must_have: MTHFR gene mutation, specifically the A1298C mutation, can interfere with the body's ability to break down the amino acid homocysteine.
MTHFR gene mutations may lead to elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood or urine.
High homocysteine levels may occur if the MTHFR enzyme is not functioning normally due to these mutations or if there is a lack of necessary nutrients such as folate or B vitamins.
Supplementation with B vitamins and folate may be necessary for people with MTHFR gene mutations to reduce health risks.
Nice_to_have: Factors such as age, smoking, and use of certain medications (like carbamazepine, methotrexate, and phenytoin) can also contribute to elevated levels of homocysteine.
It is recommended to consult a healthcare professional for guidance on nutrition or vitamin supplementation, especially for individuals with MTHFR gene mutations.

This condition also courses with flu-like symptoms. Herpes zoster can affect people of all ages but is most common among older adults. The VZV infects cells in a nerve during the primary infection (chickenpox). It does not impact the nerve cells directly, but it settles deep in the nerve. Question: What are the chances that a person with CVID, who also has a thyroid tumor, will get cancer?
Free_form_answer: 1. The long-term outlook (prognosis) and life expectancy for people with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) varies. The prognosis largely depends on whether there is severe autoimmune disease; whether there are recurrent infections that cause structural lung damage; and the development of a malignancy (cancer). Other major factors that influence prognosis include the extent of organ damage and how successfully infections can be prevented. Affected people who have only bacterial infections have a better prognosis than those with additional complications and can have nearly normal life expectancy. This is especially the case if they are diagnosed early and begin treatment soon after the onset of symptoms.

On the other hand, patients with an autoimmune condition, cancers other than lymphoma, history of splenectomy, presence of granulomatous disease, or the development of bronchiectasis alone, did not have significantly reduced survival.

Question: What are the different types of diabetes and how do they affect the body?
Free_form_answer: Diabetes is a disease in which your blood glucose, or blood sugar, levels are too high. Glucose comes from the foods you eat. Insulin is a hormone that helps the glucose get into your cells to give them energy. With type 1 diabetes, your body does not make insulin. With type 2 diabetes, the more common type, your body does not make or use insulin well. Without enough insulin, the glucose stays in your blood. You can also have prediabetes. This means that your blood sugar is higher than normal but not high enough to be called diabetes. Having prediabetes puts you at a higher risk of getting type 2 diabetes. Over time, having too much glucose in your blood can cause serious problems. It can damage your eyes, kidneys, and nerves. Diabetes can also cause heart disease, stroke and even the need to remove a limb. Pregnant women can also get diabetes, called gestational diabetes.
Must_have: The main types of diabetes are type 1, type 2, prediabetes, and gestational diabetes.
Type 1 diabetes is characterized by the body's inability to produce insulin.
In type 2 diabetes, the body either does not make enough insulin or cannot use it effectively.
Prediabetes is a condition where blood sugar levels are higher than normal but not high enough for a diabetes diagnosis and increases risk for type 2 diabetes.
Gestational diabetes occurs during pregnancy.
Long-term effects of high glucose levels in the blood can lead to serious health issues including heart disease, stroke, nerve damage, kidney disease, and eye problems.
Nice_to_have: Insulin is a hormone that helps glucose, derived from the food we eat, get efficiently used by our cells for energy.
With the different types of diabetes, either the body doesn't make insulin (type 1), doesn't use it well enough (type 2), or experiences higher than normal blood glucose levels (prediabetes).
In each type, the resultant high blood sugar levels can, over time, cause significant health complications if left unmanaged.
Pregnant women are also at risk for a type of diabetes known as gestational diabetes, though it often resolves after pregnancy.
Management and control of blood glucose levels are crucial to minimize the risk of long-term complications associated with all forms of diabetes.

Diabetes Drawer website is a comprehensive yet easy to read health portal for diabetes mellitus, the most common metabolic disease in the world. We paid special attention to diabetes prevention – we included many ways how to avoid it, what to eat and what tests and exams you must do once you are diagnosed. This blog also provides resources for diabetes educators making victory fights against this common health issue.

Many people hear the words “diabetes” and “insulin” and other medical terms associated with it, but until the disease appears at their door (either to them or to a loved one), they know little about what the disease is all about. This article seeks to address questions concerning the different types of diabetes, how they affect the body, how they can be prevented, and how to prevent them from progressing any further. Currently as of 2020, an article that was written by Health.com cited that there are around 34.2 million Americans, which is approximately 10.5 percent, who have diabetes. This is an increase from 10 years ago which had 29 million cases states wide. This is a pressing issue as the CDC stated that currently this year alone diabetics will lose an estimated 120,000 lives in 2020. Diabetes can be a serious medical condition and affect you if steps aren’t followed to keep it in moderation.

Types of Diabetes and How They Differ

Prior to attempting to determine the type of diabetes that an individual may be diagnosed with, it is essential to understand the different types and the key differences that must be noted. Although the body is dealing with a process they may be unfamiliar with, the difference between the types of diabetes is largely due to what causes the onset of the condition. Typically there are three types of diabetes: * Type 1 Diabetes * Type 2 Diabetes * Gestational Diabetes They differ from each other in several ways. Since the reason for their existence varies from one another, the management, prevention methods, and treatment options will also vary. This article will help you identify which type of diabetes you might have and help you take the right steps to deal with them.

Type 1 Diabetes and It’s Symptoms

Type 1 diabetes somewhat shares a similar name to type 2 diabetes, but the reality is that there are quite a few differences between the two. Most notably, the presence of frequent urination, uncontrolled thirst, lost weight, and excessive fatigue. As opposed to the condition that individuals with type 2 diabetes will develop, the body of a person with type 1 diabetes will make little to no insulin. This can be quite problematic as insulin is a major part of the process that allows the body to absorb and breakdown sugars, starches, and other carbohydrates. Question: Is it recommended for patients on Lipitor to have their liver function monitored by blood testing every six months.
Free_form_answer: prospective monitoring of serum enzymes upon initiating atorvastatin therapy is no longer recommended. Clinically apparent liver injury attributed to atorvastatin is usually self-limited and recovery is complete within 1 to 4 months.
Must_have: It is no longer recommended to monitor serum enzymes upon initiating atorvastatin (Lipitor) therapy.
Liver injury attributed to atorvastatin is usually self-limited and recovery is complete within 1 to 4 months.
Nice_to_have: Patients who are experiencing symptoms that may indicate liver damage, such as persistent nausea, stomach pain, or jaundice, should seek medical attention immediately.

Answer:

Step 1/2
First, it is important to understand that Lipitor (atorvastatin) is a statin medication used to lower cholesterol levels in the blood. Statins work by inhibiting the production of cholesterol in the liver. While statins are generally considered safe and effective, they can cause side effects in some people, including liver damage. Liver damage can occur when the liver is unable to break down the medication properly, leading to an accumulation of the drug in the body. This can cause symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice).

Step 2/2
Therefore, it is recommended that patients on Lipitor have their liver function monitored by blood testing every six months. This is especially important for patients who are at a higher risk of liver damage, such as those with a history of liver disease or those who are taking other medications that can affect liver function. By monitoring liver function, healthcare providers can detect any changes early and adjust the medication dosage or treatment plan as needed. In summary, it is recommended for patients on Lipitor to have their liver function monitored by blood testing every six months to ensure their safety and effectiveness of the medication.

Symptoms of Osteogenesis Imperfecta can range from frequent bone fractures resulting from little or no trauma, blue sclerae, short stature, hearing loss, respiratory problems, and dentinogenesis imperfecta.

Symptoms of EDS can include back pain, double-jointedness, easily damaged and bruised skin, easy scarring and poor wound healing, flat feet, increased joint mobility, joint dislocation, joint pain, premature rupture of membranes during pregnancy and very soft and velvety skin.
Nice_to_have: Whereas symptoms of Osteogenesis Imperfecta are more related to bone, hearing and dental health, EDS symptoms are often related to joints, skin and vision.
Mild forms of Osteogenesis Imperfecta, including type I, are characterized by bone fractures during childhood and adolescence often the result of minor trauma.

Whereas the more severe forms, causing frequent bone fractures may begin before birth and result from little or no trauma, in the most severe forms particularly type II, infants often die shortly after birth due to life threatening problems with breathing caused by an abnormally small, fragile rib cage and underdeveloped lungs.Although the two conditions share some symptoms such as joint pain, hearing loss among others, they are distinctive conditions with unique symptoms and should not be mistaken to be the same.
It's highly recommended that one consults a genetic counselor or health professional for guidance.

Question: How does trisomy 7 affect the body and are there any treatments for it?
Free_form_answer: 1. Trisomy 7 is extremely rare at birth and is generally considered lethal in embryogenesis. All surviving children are mosaics with variable and nonspecific clinical features. Chromosomal mosaicism may be suggested by body asymmetry and/or Blaschkolinear skin pigmentary dysplasia associated with developmental delay. Cultured skin fibroblasts cytogenetic analysis confirms mosaicism and identifies its chromosomal origin. In amniocytes, trisomy 7 is frequently a cell culture artifact leading to single- or multiple-cell pseudomosaicism with normal fetal outcome.2. 7q11.23 duplication syndrome is considered to be an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of chromosome 7 with the duplication in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases result from a duplication that occurs during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early fetal development. These cases occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family. Less commonly, an affected person inherits the chromosome with a duplicated segment from a parent.3. Rearrangements of chromosomes include deletions of DNA sequences and duplications of segments, both of which can encompass thousands to hundreds of thousands of bases. Why do these large rearrangements occur? For one, certain structural features of the genome, also referred to as genome architecture, can render various regions fragile and thus prone to events such as chromosome breakage, which often result in translocations, deletions, and duplications. Often, these alterations happen due to errors during cell division when chromosomes align (Figure 1). Homologous recombination between areas of concentrated repeated sequences frequently creates deletions and duplications. Because they commonly involve more than one gene, the disorders caused by these large deletion and duplication mutations are often severe.
Must_have: Trisomy 7 is generally considered lethal in embryogenesis and surviving children are mosaics with variable and nonspecific clinical features.
There is no specific treatment for Trisomy 7, as it is a chromosomal abnormality.
Nice_to_have: 7q11.23 duplication syndrome is considered to be an autosomal dominant condition, which means one copy of the duplicated chromosome 7 in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.
Rearrangements of chromosomes include deletions of DNA sequences and duplications of segments, both of which can encompass thousands to hundreds of thousands of bases.
These alterations often happen due to errors during cell division when chromosomes align.
Homologous recombination between areas of concentrated repeated sequences frequently creates deletions and duplications.

Question: What are the effects of smoking and/or nicotine on the digestive system?
Free_form_answer: 1. Smoking has been found to increase the risk of cancers of the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and pancreas. Research suggests that smoking may also increase the risk of cancers of the liver, colon, and rectum. Smoking increases the risk of heartburn and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Smoking increases the risk of peptic ulcers. Smoking may worsen some liver diseases, including primary biliary cirrhosis and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Current and former smokers have a higher risk of developing Crohn's disease than people who have never smoked. People who smoke are more likely to develop colon polyps. Smoking increases the risk of developing pancreatitis. Some studies have shown that smoking may increase the risk of developing gallstones.
Must_have: Smoking increases the risk of cancers of the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and pancreas.
Additionally, smoking increases the risk of heartburn, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcers, primary biliary cirrhosis, and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
Current and former smokers are at a higher risk of developing Crohn's disease and colon polyps.
Smoking can also lead to pancreatitis and exacerbate some liver diseases.
Lastly, nicotine has been found to have harmful effects on the gastric mucosa, by enhancing gastric aggressive factors and reducing defensive factors.
Nice_to_have: Some studies have suggested smoking may increase the risk of developing gallstones.

Nicotine enhances acid and pepsin secretions, gastric motility, and duodenogastric reflux of bile salts, along with increasing the risk of Helicobacter pylori infection, free radicals, platelet-activating factor, and vasopressin secretion.

Furthermore, nicotine has been found to impair the therapeutic effect of H2-receptor antagonists and decrease prostaglandin synthesis, gastric mucosal blood flow, mucus secretion, and epidermal growth factor secretion.
It's important to consider these effects when assessing the overall health impact of smoking and nicotine use.

Question: Does Fibromyalgia cause swelling in your body?
Free_form_answer: 1. Fibromyalgia is a disorder that causes muscle pain and fatigue. People with fibromyalgia have "tender points" on the body. Tender points are specific places on the neck, shoulders, back, hips, arms, and legs. These points hurt when pressure is put on them.
Must_have: Fibromyalgia is a disorder that is characterized by muscle pain, fatigue, and tender points on the body, but it does not typically cause swelling.
Symptoms of fibromyalgia can include trouble sleeping, morning stiffness, headaches, painful menstrual periods, and tingling or numbness in hands and feet.
Nice_to_have: Swelling in the body, particularly in the feet, legs, and ankles, is common under certain conditions such as after long periods of inactivity, being overweight, aging, having a leg infection or a blood clot in the leg, following injury or surgery involving the leg, ankle, or foot.

Swelling can also be a side effect of certain medications, and may occur in women who take estrogen or during parts of the menstrual cycle, as well as during pregnancy, and can also be a sign of heart failure, kidney failure, or liver failure.

Question: Can cancer spread through blood contact?
Free_form_answer: A healthy person cannot "catch" cancer from someone who has it. There is no evidence that close contact or things like sex, kissing, touching, sharing meals, or breathing the same air can spread cancer from one person to another.
Must_have: Healthy individuals cannot contract cancer from another person through blood contact.
The immune system of a healthy individual recognizes and destroys foreign cells, including cancer cells from another person.
Nice_to_have: There is no evidence to suggest that cancer can be spread through close contact, sexual intimacy, touching, shared meals, or shared air.
Cancer cells from one person are generally unable to survive within the body of another healthy person.

You may have heard of bloodborne cancers in people or animals, but is this a risk for everyone? The risk of bloodborne cancer depends on what you have in mind. For example, cancers rarely spread into the bloodstream of the affected person, so it's only considered a factor if the person has an advanced cancer that has begun spreading. But in most cases, neither cancer nor cancerous cells enter the bloodstream unless there's plenty of time and resources for it to happen. The risk of cancer through shared blood with someone else depends heavily on factors like cleanliness or risk level in one's environment. In other words, it can be very specific. Even so, several conditions can heighten cancer risks — resulting from contact with another's (or sometimes even your own) blood.

What does cancer look like in the blood?

Your blood supplies the life-sustaining nutrients essential for one's body to function properly. Any disease or cell growth can trouble the blood and cause it to look abnormal. If you have cancer or blood cells in your system, they may be detected by a tumor on a scan or a microscopic examination of your blood. But cancer doesn't always appear in the blood like this. Cancerous cells may not look too different from normal blood cells, so the diseased cells spread through one's bloodstream for quite awhile before they're discovered. And by the time they're noticed, often many years have pass. The chances are higher that cancer can spread into the blood when a person's immune system is weakened or if they are currently treating cancer. Fortunately, though, the risk of this happening is slim when you're not undergoing treatment. That said, examining the blood is an effective way of tracking cancerous growth. Treating the symptoms or performing additional tests won't necessarily help in these situations. Any affected cells should be removed through chemotherapy (or similar) and resected. This is essential to stopping the spread of cancer and stopping it from reaching the blood in the first place.

Question: What is plantar fasiciitis, and how is it treated?
Free_form_answer: You are more likely to get plantar fasciitis if you:Treatment options for plantar fasciitis may include physical therapies such as stretches and exercises, which can help strengthen your plantar fascia and Achilles tendon and improve your stability. Treating plantar fasciitis may also involve the use of over-the-counter pain relievers and anti-inflammatories, orthotic shoe inserts which can help distribute pressure more equally across your foot, corticosteroid injections, and in severe cases, surgery. Resting and staying off your feet can also help alleviate some of the pain caused by plantar fasciitis.
Must_have: Physical therapies, strengthening exercises, over-the-counter pain relievers and anti-inflammatories, orthotic shoe inserts, corticosteroid injections, rest, and in severe cases, surgery are common treatment options for plantar fasciitis.
Plantar fasciitis is a common cause of heel pain involving inflammation of a thick band of tissue running across the bottom of your foot.
Nice_to_have: Factors that can increase your risk of plantar fasciitis include having foot arch problems, running long distances or on uneven surfaces, sudden weight gain, having a tight Achilles tendon, wearing shoes with poor arch support or soft soles, and changing your activities.

Plantar fasciitis is a common cause of heel pain. It is caused by inflammation of the plantar fascia, a thick band of tissue that runs along the bottom of the foot from the heel to the toes.

The plantar fascia helps to support the arch of the foot and absorbs shock when walking or running. When it becomes inflamed, it can cause pain and stiffness in the heel and arch of the foot.

Plantar fasciitis is often caused by overuse, such as running or walking on hard surfaces, or by wearing shoes that do not provide adequate support. It can also be caused by obesity, flat feet, or high arches.

Treatment for plantar fasciitis typically involves rest, ice, and stretching exercises. In some cases, a doctor may recommend physical therapy or orthotics to help correct the underlying cause of the condition.

If you are experiencing heel pain, it is important to see a doctor to determine the cause and receive appropriate treatment.

Plantar fasciitis is one of the most common causes of heel pain. The plantar fascia is a band of tissue that extends under the sole of the foot from the heel bones toward the toes. The band is attached to the heel bone (the calcaneus) via a strong ligament, called the calcaneal tubercle, that stretches to the arch of the foot.

Plantar fasciitis occurs when the plantar fascia becomes inflamed due to the mechanical overloading of the plantar fascia through micronics trauma. This has been attributed to exercises that stress the soles of the feet, including running long distances, aerobics training, weightlifting, and aerobics dancing. Chronically tight Achilles tendon, poor stance alignment, and excessive pronation of the foot are all risk-increasing factors.

The symptoms of plantar fasciitis include pain, swelling, and abnormal skin sensations (usually pain) along the plantar sole. Pain tends to be worse early in the morning and lasts for several hours until sufficient "warm-up" has occurred.

The initial management is very conservative and involves analgesic and anti-inflammatory drugs, foot splints at night, physical therapy, ultra-sound therapy, prescription foot orthotics, extracorporeal shock wave therapy, cortisone injections, cryotherapy.

When after 6 months there is no significant improvement in pain, then one should think about the need for more aggressive treatment which involves plantar fascia release. Surgical treatment must be considered as the final decision after careful examination.

Must_have: Upper GI endoscopy is capable of identifying a variety of diseases, but it cannot detect liver cancer or lymph nodes.
The detection of liver cancer typcially involves imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT or MRI, or biopsy procedures like needle biopsy, laparoscopic biopsy, or surgical biopsy.
Nice_to_have: In addition to imaging and biopsy procedures, lab tests may also be used in the detection of liver cancer.
Upper GI endoscopy can identify conditions such as anemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, ulcers, cancer, inflammation, precancerous abnormalities, and celiac disease.

Question: Can an abscessed tooth cause a heart attack?
Free_form_answer: 1. A heart attack happens if the flow of oxygen-rich blood to a section of heart muscle suddenly becomes blocked and the heart can't get oxygen. Most heart attacks occur as a result of coronary heart disease (CHD).
Must_have: An abscessed tooth can potentially lead to an infection spreading to the heart known as infective endocarditis, if bacteria from the tooth abscess get into the bloodstream and attach to certain areas of the heart.
This is more common in individuals with damaged or artificial heart valves, congenital heart defects, or implanted heart devices, but can occur in people with normal heart valves as well.
Poor dental hygiene and unhealthy teeth and gums increase the risk for infection.
Nice_to_have: Infective endocarditis is a serious condition that can cause damage to the heart, leading to serious and sometimes fatal complications.
It can develop quickly, known as acute infective endocarditis, or slowly, known as subacute infective endocarditis.
Although there is a potential link between an abscessed tooth and heart issues, it's important to understand that most heart attacks are a result of coronary heart disease.

I always get a little sympathetic pain in my chest when I floss, so it no longer surprised me when the dentist discovered some tooth decay, cavities, and gum disease. I've always treated it like an inconvenience. But when I have to take better care of my teeth, it feels like a sacrifice. My doctor has told me for years that I need to "take better care of my teeth and body," but I've never felt what that really meant. Then I started having chest pain, and now I understand why. I have been hesitant to write this post, but I know that many others go through the same thing, so maybe they can find some solace here.

At that moment, I knew that I had a heart attack coming. A few weeks before this, I had an attack of pain in the stomach area. doctors ruled out heart disease, and I was told that it was just a minor stomach infection. I just shrugged it off and decided to ignore all the warnings about taking my medicine too early and which types of food to avoid. After all, I was just getting my next attack.

Then I got bad at it. the heart attack came when I was walking down the street. I started to feel as though something stuck in my throat and I couldn't take in a deep breath. My skin started to turn clammy, and I started to sweat. I felt so bad that I lay down to rest, and the next thing I knew, I was flat out on the floor and just thinking about how my heart stopped. Total heart attack with very little forethought.

I managed to do it, though. Before I had the attack, I had been on a flight going into a serious health problem, and I pressed my body into the chair, panting for air, my heart pounding out of my chest. I knew the signs and symptoms, and I thought that maybe I was having chest pain or something. I knew I was having a hard time catching my breath, and I felt as though my heart was pounding.

I looked up what to expect from a heart attack. My doctor told my parents then that they wouldn't find any obstruction in my arteries. She said that it's very rare that people die from heart attacks. But I was still worried.

Question: Define Syncope (ischemic stroke)?
Free_form_answer: 1. The defining characteristics of syncope include rapid onset with transient loss of consciousness usually accompanied by falling, followed by spontaneous, complete, and usually prompt recovery without intervention. Because some patients use the term dizziness to describe syncopal events, it is important to ask patients exactly what they mean by dizziness and whether loss of consciousness occurred.
Must_have: Syncope is characterized by rapid onset, transient loss of consciousness usually followed by falling and it needs to be differentiated from vertigo, coma, drop attacks, dizziness, sudden cardiac death, and seizures.
It is important to ask patients about their symptoms to determine if syncope has occurred.

In the context of ischemic stroke, Transient ischemic attack (TIA) versus mimics should be diagnosed correctly and early as early interventions can lead to significant reduction in risk of recurrent ischemic events.
Nice_to_have: Some patients describe syncope events as dizziness.
Drop attacks could be due to underlying cardiovascular disease, blockage of arteries or cerebral aqueduct or vertebrobasilar stroke with immediate recovery and no loss of consciousness.
In 15 percent of syncopal patients, limb jerking could be a symptom but other sign of seizures would be absent.
TIA mimics are more likely with gradual onset of symptoms and nonspecific symptoms like memory loss or headache.

Question: What doctor specializes in testing for and treating autoimmune diseases?
Free_form_answer: Since autoimmune diseases vary greatly in presentation, many different physician specialists care for patients with these disorders. The specialist is usually skilled in treating diseases of a particular system. For example: rheumatologists tend to treat diseases affecting the joints and connective tissue; neurologists, autoimmune diseases of the central and/or peripheral nervous system; dermatologists; diseases of the skin; gastroenterologists, diseases of the intestinal tract; and endocrinologists, diseases of endocrine organs. It can be truly said that physicians of any specialty may encounter patients with autoimmune disease.
Must_have: Autoimmune diseases can be diagnosed and treated by different specialist physicians depending on the system or tissue affected by the disease.
These specialists can include rheumatologists, neurologists, dermatologists, gastroenterologists, and endocrinologists.
Nice_to_have: Due to the varying nature of autoimmune diseases, physicians from any specialty may encounter patients with these disorders.
Therefore it's crucial to have a thorough diagnosis depending on the symptoms and the organ system affected by the disease.

Question: What is aortic stenosis, and is there anything I should do about it?
Free_form_answer: The aorta is the main artery that carries blood out of the heart to the rest of the body. Blood flows out of the heart and into the aorta through the aortic valve. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve does not open fully. This decreases blood flow from the heart. As a result, the heart has to work harder to pump blood into the aorta, which can lead to symptoms like fainting, chest pain, or heart failure over time. Aortic stenosis can occur due to aging or birth defects, but whatever the cause, it’s important to monitor and manage this condition to prevent further complications.If you’ve been diagnosed with aortic stenosis, your doctor will usually monitor the condition regularly, often through echocardiograms, to keep an eye on the progression. Treatment will depend on how severe your stenosis is. Options can range from regular monitoring and medication to surgery or a less invasive procedure known as a Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR) to replace the narrowed valve.

If you have aortic stenosis, you may be worried about it because it is a condition in which the aortic valve becomes narrowed. Let’s discuss what aortic stenosis is, the risk factors, symptoms, diagnosis, treatments and more.

What is Aortic Stenosis

Aortic stenosis is a disease that occurs when a person’s aortic valve narrows or stiffens. The aortic valve is located between the heart and the aorta (the large blood vessel that goes throughout your body). It circulates blood to every part of the body, including your brain, lungs, kidneys, legs, and arms. Aortic stenosis is a serious condition that if left untreated may be life-threatening.

What Causes Aortic Stenosis

Two common causes of aortic stenosis are congenital and acquired. However, the two can be combined. A person can be born with a narrow aortic opening, which is considered the congenital form of aortic stenosis. Generally, this does not need treatment until later in life. Another type of aortic stenosis can occur as the individual ages.

Congenital Aortic Stenosis

Congenital aortic stenosis occurs when a child is born with a narrowed aortic valve. This is a result of the improper formation of the valve during the development of an embryo. Sometimes in children, an aortic valve that is not closed properly at birth may be corrected by surgery or by balloon dilation. The problem with correction at a young age is that it weakens the aortic valve. This may result in the aortic valve not closing completely when the heart pumps. This is not necessarily bad at a young age, but it becomes extremely dangerous when the valve is exhausted from the continuous incomplete closure. The diseased aortic valve will not close all the way every time the heart beats. That means some blood that normally would be pumped into the aorta is pushed backwards into the left ventricle. The blood also is seeping back through the aortic valve into the heart and back up the lungs. The heart’s 1st chamber (known as the right atrium), must work harder. The pulmonary artery can begin to enlarge, this can also be called pulmonic hypertension.

Acquired Aortic Stenosis

Aortic stenosis can also develop over time. This form is commonly caused by calcification of the valve, which occurs with age or as a result of other conditions, such as high blood pressure or heart valve diseases.
